2.text: Hear, O wise men, my words, And, O knowing ones, give ear to me.

3.text: For the ear doth try words, And the palate tasteth to eat.

4.text: Judgment let us choose for ourselves, Let us know among ourselves what is good.

5.text: For Job hath said, ‘I have been righteous, And God hath turned aside my right,

6.text: Against my right do I lie? Mortal is mine arrow—without transgression.’

7.text: Who is a man like Job? He drinketh scoffing like water,

8.text: And he hath travelled for company With workers of iniquity, So as to go with men of wickedness.

9.text: For he hath said, ‘It doth not profit a man, When he delighteth himself with God.’

10.text: Therefore, O men of heart, hearken to me; Far be it from God to do wickedness, And from the Mighty to do perverseness:

11.text: For the work of man he repayeth to him, And according to the path of each He doth cause him to find.

12.text: Yea, truly, God doth not do wickedly, And the Mighty doth not pervert judgment.

13.text: Who hath inspected for Himself the earth? And who hath placed all the habitable world?

14.text: If He doth set on him His heart, His spirit and his breath unto Him He gathereth.

15.text: Expire doth all flesh together, And man to dust returneth.

16.text: And if there is understanding, hear this, Give ear to the voice of my words.

17.text: Yea, doth one hating justice govern? Or the Most Just dost thou condemn?

18.text: Who hath said to a king—‘Worthless,’ Unto princes—‘Wicked?’

19.text: That hath not accepted the person of princes, Nor hath known the rich before the poor, For a work of His hands are all of them.

20.text: In a moment they die, and at midnight Shake do people, and they pass away, And they remove the mighty without hand.

21.text: For His eyes are on the ways of each, And all his steps He doth see.

22.text: There is no darkness nor death-shade, For workers of iniquity to be hidden there;

23.text: For He doth not suffer man any more, To go unto God in judgment,

24.text: He breaketh the mighty—no searching! And He appointeth others in their stead.

25.text: Therefore He knoweth their works, And He hath overturned by night, And they are bruised.

26.text: As wicked He hath stricken them, In the place of beholders.

27.text: Because that against right They have turned aside from after Him, And none of His ways have considered wisely,

28.text: To cause to come in unto Him The cry of the poor, And the cry of the afflicted He heareth.

29.text: And He giveth rest, and who maketh wrong? And hideth the face, and who beholdeth it? And in reference to a nation and to a man, It is the same.

30.text: From the reigning of a profane man, From the snares of a people;

31.text: For unto God hath any said: ‘I have taken away, I do not corruptly,

32.text: Besides that which I see, shew Thou me, If iniquity I have done—I do not add?’

33.text: By thee doth He recompense, That thou hast refused—That thou dost choose, and not I? And what thou hast known, speak.

34.text: Let men of heart say to me, And a wise man is hearkening to me.

35.text: Job—not with knowledge doth he speak, And his words are not with wisdom.

36.text: My Father! let Job be tried—unto victory, Because of answers for men of iniquity,

37.text: For he doth add to his sin, Transgression among us he vomiteth, And multiplieth his sayings to God.
